p: In the health sciences, an important milestone for openness was achieved 20 years ago, as genetic sequencing began to generate massive amounts of data and scientists agreed to deposit sequences in public databases almost as they were produced. Encouraged by the discoveries this facilitated, life science leaders convened summits that extended the call for openness to other types of datasets [ 8]. Major public health research funders agreed to increase the availability of research data and to promote the use of those data to accelerate advances in public health [ 9]. Today, the movement towards open science is evident across the health sciences landscape ( Box 2), including recent emergencies.
